question: Should we offer amnesty to bloggers currently prosecuted by their native states?

content.source_1: UN Human Rights Committee, General Comment No. 34 on Article 19 (Freedoms of opinion and expression) (2011) — Interprets ICCPR protections to mean states should not criminalize mere criticism of institutions or leaders and that imprisonment is never an appropriate penalty for defamation; many prosecutions of bloggers therefore contravene international human rights law, supporting calls for release or clemency. https://www.ohchr.org/en/documents/general-comments-and-recommendations/general-comment-no-34-article-19-freedoms-opinion-expression
content.source_2: Freedom House, Freedom on the Net 2024 — Documents a fourteenth consecutive year of global decline in internet freedom and widespread arrests and prosecutions for online expression; provides empirical evidence that criminal cases against bloggers are part of a broader pattern that chills speech and undermines democratic participation, bolstering arguments for protective relief. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2024
content.source_3: OHCHR, Rabat Plan of Action on the prohibition of advocacy of national, racial or religious hatred that constitutes incitement (2012) — Sets a six-part threshold for when expression crosses into criminal incitement under ICCPR Article 20; emphasizes that some speech legitimately attracts criminal sanctions, cautioning against blanket amnesties that might shield advocacy of violence or hatred. https://www.ohchr.org/en/documents/consolidated-reports/rabat-plan-action-prohibition-advocacy-national-racial-or-religious-hatred
content.source_4: UNHCR, Guidelines on International Protection No. 10: Claims to refugee status related to freedom of expression (2015) — Explains that individuals persecuted for online expression (including bloggers) may qualify for refugee status; clarifies the appropriate international remedy is asylum or humanitarian admission by third states, not “amnesty” from another state’s criminal jurisdiction. https://www.unhcr.org/publications/legal/5661937d9/guidelines-international-protection-no-10-claims-refugee-status-related
content.source_5: BBC News, “Saudi blogger Raif Badawi freed from prison” (2022) — Case study of a blogger sentenced to 10 years in prison and 1,000 lashes for online writings; release followed sustained international advocacy, illustrating both the severity of punitive measures against bloggers and the potential impact of external protective interventions. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-60707841
content.source_6: OHCHR, Rule-of-Law Tools for Post-Conflict States: Amnesties (2009) — UN policy guidance warning that broad or categorical amnesties can undermine accountability and the rule of law; while focused on serious crimes, it underscores general risks of blanket amnesty policies and supports targeted, case-by-case approaches rather than wholesale amnesty for all bloggers. https://www.ohchr.org/en/publications/policy-and-methodological-publications/rule-law-tools-post-conflict-states-amnesties
